questions.text: Mother of a 2-week-old girl comes to clinic for observed pauses in child's sleep. She says that she now sleeps with her daughter sleeping on her stomach to make sure she is breathing. What test would be most helpful is assessing her breathing pattern while she sleeps?
questions.solution:
• Assessing the function of the respiratory control centers is not straightforward.
  • Polysomnography measures a wide variety of physiologic variables during sleep, including nasal and oral airflow, chest and abdominal wall motion, oxygen saturation (SpO2), end-tidal (exhaled) pCO2, and electrocardiogram.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 116)

questions.text: Viruses associated with arthritis include all of the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Common causes of Viral arthritis include, Parvovirus, Hepatitis B & C, Cytomegalovirus, Flavivirus & Rubella.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1171)

questions.text: All of the following diseases are known to be complicated by reactive amyloidosis (AA type) EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• A number of chronic inflammatory rheumatic diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA), juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), ankylosing spondylitis, as well as hereditary autoinflammatory diseases, have an increased risk for the development of AA amyloidosis.
  • AA amyloidosis has also been associated with granulomatous diseases such as sarcoidosis, cystic fibrosis, Crohn disease, malignancies such as mesothelioma and Hodgkin diseases, intravenous drug abuse, and other infections, such as bronchiectasis and HIV.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1205)

questions.text: A 16-year-old sexually active woman is being seen in the emergency department. She is complaining of vaginal discharge. She has a temperature of 99.5°F, but is otherwise well. On pelvic examination, you see a mucopurulent cervical discharge with scant blood. Samples of the discharge are sent to the laboratory for culture. There are no cervical ulcers noted. She does not have any medical allergies. Which of the following is the most common sexually transmitted infection in adolescents?
questions.solution:
• This young woman has cervicitis, but without evidence of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  • Chlamydia is the most common bacterial cause of sexually transmitted diseases and the most likely etiology of this patient’s infection.
  • Gonorrhea would be the next most likely cause and, frequently, there will be coinfection with the two pathogens.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 988)

choices.text: They do not require SBE prophylaxis
They do not have conduction tissue running on their inferior margin
If large, they can cause cardiac failure in 1st week of life
Usually causes no audible cardiac murmur on the 1st day of life

questions.text: False statement for muscular ventricular septal defect is
questions.solution:
• Muscular VSD occur in the muscular part of the ventricular septum, SBE prophylaxis is no longer indicated now.
  • The conduction tissue is located in the inferiorly in a peri membranous septal defect, where surgeons need to avoid the area when suturing a patch in place to close the defect.
  • If VSD is large, patients present with the symptoms of cardiac failure after the first week of life.
  • The pulmonary resistance is high at birth, and hence there is little shunt between the two ventricles and therefore no audible murmur in the first 24 hours.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2194)

choices.text: A harsh pansystolic murmur with the diagnosis of VSD
A harsh systolic murmur in TGA without associated defects
Severe acidosis and poor pulses with hypoplastic left heart syndrome

questions.text: On 1st day of life, which of the following may be found in neonates with congenital heart disease?
questions.solution:
• Babies presenting with left-right shunt will have no murmur or symptoms on the first day of life, because the pulmonary vascular resistance has yet to fall.
  • Similarly, any common mixing disease, such as atrioventricular septal defect, can present with severe cyanosis on 1st day of life, with high pulmonary vascular resistance, before breathlessness and heart failure develop at 1 week of age or more.
  • All obstructed left heart lesions, such as coarctation of aorta and hypoplastic left heart syndrome, tend to present with acidosis and weak pulses in the first few days of life.

(Ref. Park’s textbook of Paediatric Cardiology, 6th ed., pg. 155)

choices.text: A 6-week-old lying in the supine position will show extension at the elbows, hips and knees
A 2-month-old held in ventral suspension will not be able to hold his head in the line with his body
A 3-month-old in the prone position will lift his head and upper chest, supported by his forearms
A 6-month-old would be expected to sit unsupported and reach out for nearby objects

questions.text: True statement about gross motor development and posture is
questions.solution:
• At 6 weeks, baby placed in supine position will classically show a flexed posture at elbows, hips and knees. An extended posture may indicate cerebral palsy.
  • A 6-week-old held in ventral suspension will be expected to be able to hold his head in line of the body.
  • At 3 months, a baby placed face down should be able to lift their head and upper chest supported by forearms
  • After 9 months of age, baby would be able to sit totally unsupported while reaching out to grasp objects.

(Ref. Illingworth’s The development of Infant & Child)

choices.text: Condition should be important and rare
An identified and available treatment pathway
Early intervention to be as effective as late intervention at improving outcome

questions.text: Which of the following is an essential criterion for a screening test?
questions.solution:
• Successful screening tests require the condition to be important, with a well understood natural history and epidemiology. The test itself should be cost effective, acceptable to the patient and family, sensitive and specific.
  • The treatment pathway should be clearly understood, available, evidence based and should provide an early intervention that improves outcome.
  • The screening program should be effective at reducing mortality and morbidity, cost effective and acceptable to the community as a whole. It will require continuing quality assurance and audit.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 127)

choices.text: It is never acceptable to cut a coated tablet
Dispersible tablets always form a uniform concentration when dissolved in water
Not all non-coated tablets are dispersible in water
Suppositories easily cut to give accurate dosing in children

questions.text: The following statements relating to pediatric dosing that requires alteration of a product designed for adults are true
questions.solution:
• Plain tablets with no special release mechanisms may be suitable for crushing, but the particles may not disperse in water at all, leaving all the particles on the bottom of the vessel.
  • It is never advisable to cut a coated tablet, but in the absence of any other product it may be acceptable, if the coat has no modifying-release properties such as a basic sugar coat.
  • Just because a tablet is dispersible, it doesn’t mean it dissolves to form a uniform solution.
  • Suppositories may not have the medication dispersed evenly throughout the product, and thus cutting is not desirable in terms of accurate dosing.

(Ref. Goodman & Gilman’s Pharmacological basis of therapeutics, 13th ed., pg. 34)

choices.text: Steroid creams/ointments should be stopped in eczema herpeticum
Wet wraps are an effective treatment for infected eczema
Failure to respond to a course of oral antibiotic is the result of MRSA infection
Topical antibiotic is the treatment of choice

questions.text: True statement regarding infected atopic eczema is?
questions.solution:
• Steroid creams would encourage viral spread and hence avoided in eczema herpeticum.
  • Wet wraps are discontinued if there is overt skin infection.
  • There are many reasons due to which child might not respond to oral antibiotic lie too short a course given, flucloxacillin only given, and group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus is present in addition to Staphylococcus aureus, erythromycin resistance, nasal Staphylococcus carriage.
  • Use of topical antibiotics is for localizing infections only, and those such as fusidic acid should not be used for more than 5 days, due to risk of bacterial resistance.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1116)

choices.text: A history of marked hyperactivity for 6 months duration should be present before making the diagnosis
The diagnosis should be made before school entry if possible
Once treatment with methylphenidate is commenced, educational support is rarely needed

questions.text: True statement about attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is?
questions.solution:
• ADHD is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity and impulsiveness. The behavior should have been present for 6 months but not all three features have to be present.
  • Management involves a comprehensive treatment program and close communication with the school is vital.
  • Methylphenidate does not cure ADHD but improves the symptoms to allow other behavioral interventions an opportunity to take effect.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paaediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 200)

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is referred by a general practitioner with concerns about speech and language development. Antenatal and neonatal history is insignificant. At 15 months he had five clear words that he has stopped using since. He enjoys puzzles, is able to feed using a spoon and fork, and can dress with help. There has been a difficulty admitting into nursery. He becomes very physically aggressive towards other children. On assessment he is very difficult to settle and tries to escape. He does not follows simple commands and refuses to engage in simple activities. What is the most likely explanation for the condition?
questions.solution:
• From the history some of his development is age appropriate, so global developmental delay is ruled out.
  • History and his behavior make specific speech and language delay unlikely.
  • Attention deficit is a possibility but regression of language at around 15 months of age is not explained by it. Also, difficult to consider diagnosis of ADHD at this young age.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 182)

choices.text: In girls, pubarche is before thelarche
Menarche means complete cessation of growth in girls
FSH in boys stimulates testosterone production

questions.text: True statement about puberty is
questions.solution:
• Thelarche is before pubarche.
  • Upto 75% boys have some component of gynecomastia due to rise in estrogen levels initially compared to testosterone.
  • Following menarche in girls, there is marked reduction in height velocity but not complete cessation of growth.
  • In boys, FSH stimulates the Sertoli cells for spermatogenesis and LH stimulates the Leydig cells for testosterone production.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2655)

choices.text: In neonate can occur in infants of mother with both active and inactive hyperthyroidism
In childhood secondary to Graves disease is not usually associated with a thyroid goiter
Commonly has an acute onset in childhood
That is treated medically will result in long term remission in 50% of children within 2 years

questions.text: True statement about hyperthyroidism is
questions.solution:
• Neonatal hyperthyroidism is caused by transplacental transfer of maternal TSH receptor antibodies.
  • Children with graves disease have some enlargement of thyroid gland.
  • The onset in childhood is usually insidious and has often been present for some time prior to diagnosis.
  • About 50% of children treated medically will be in long term remission by 4 years with a continued remission rate of 25% every 2 years after this until 6 years of treatment.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2680)

choices.text: It is expected to be resolved with sedation
It is a direct cause of testicular damage
It should be treated with gallows traction

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy presents to you for the first time with complaint of swelling in groin, gradually increasing over time. On examination you found it to be an inguinal hernia that is not reducible. True statement about this condition is?
questions.solution:
• Irreducible inguinal hernia may exert pressure on the spermatic cord and compromise testicular blood supply, resulting in testicular ischemia.
  • Herniotomy is ideally performed several days after the hernia is reduced. This delay allows local inguinal edema to resolve and reduces the chances of operative injury to the cord.
  • Gallows traction, relying on the gravity to reduce hernia is an obsolete technique.
  • The hernia should be reduced immediately on arrival at hospital using firm but gentle pressure to squeeze the sac content back into the abdomen. This closed reduction procedure is painful and might require local anesthesia. Babies in whom closed reduction fails, open reduction is done and in this group in many patients, it reduced spontaneously during induction of anesthesia.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1908)

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with vomiting, abdominal pain and rectal bleeding. He is dehydrated and there is an abdominal mass. A meckel's scan is negative. What is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In this age group with these presentations, intussusception is the most likely diagnosis.
  • Closest differential is enteric duplication which has similar presentation, but relatively a rarer entity. Also, many of the duplications gives Meckel’s scan positive.
  • Similarly, Midgut volvulus is rare in this age group compared to intussusception.
  • Acute appendicitis can have gut obstruction but it would not have abdominal mass.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1813)

choices.text: Yellow nails are one of the features
It is commonest cause of polyposis in childhood

questions.text: True statement about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is
questions.solution:
• Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, is one of the causes of GI polyposis.
  • Inheritance is autosomal dominant.
  • It is pre-malignant with an increased risk of gastrointestinal cancer and ovarian tumors.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1901)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Behcet syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Behcet syndrome is characterized by orogenital ulcer with or without non-erosive arthritis, thrombophlebitis, vascular thromboses or CNS abnormalities including meningoencephalitis.
  • Treatment of orogenital ulcer is often unsatisfactory, although local or systemic steroids may be used acutely.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 3110)

questions.text: In a child with suspected pancreatic insufficiency and cystic fibrosis is ruled out, the most useful investigation will be?
questions.solution:
• α1 antitrypsin is a serum protein. It is not present in the diet. Fecal levels reflect enteric protein loss (protein losing enteropathy).
  • Chromatography will detect carbohydrate intolerance.
  • Calprotectin found in feces is a simple and non-invasive measure of bowel inflammation.
  • Elastase is a pancreas-specific enzyme which is stable during intestinal transport and is stable in feces. It is a reliable indicator of pancreatic function.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1912)

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with a 6-week history of abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea and weight loss. Platelet count is raised but other inflammatory markers are normal. Stool culture is negative. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Crohn’s and Ulcerative colitis both are possibilities here. But inflammatory markers are almost universally raised in Crohn’s disease and so the normal CRP favors ulcerative colitis.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1823)

questions.text: An 8-month-old baby presents to you with persistence of diarrhea after recent rotaviral infection. Which of the following type of feeds are suggested in this scenario?
questions.solution:
• This child probably has developed a transient carbohydrate intolerance after viral infection. This is common in children after rotaviral infection.
  • Treatment is with lactose exclusion until symptoms resolve and then reintroduction of a normal feed after 4-6 weeks.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1847)

choices.text: Is usually seen in offspring of men with myotonic dystrophy
Is most likely outcome in offspring of an affected female

questions.text: True statement about Congenital myotonic dystrophy among the following is?
questions.solution:
• Myotonic dystrophy is Autosomal dominant condition caused by a triplet repeat expansion mutation in the DMPK gene.
  • The expansion is at greatest risk of further expansion when transmitted through a female and this accounts for the observed tendency to increasing severity in successive generations, known as anticipation. Expansion to the size associated with congenital onset rarely reproduce.
  • For an affected woman, there is 50% chance that they will pass on the mutant allele, which could remain stable or only enlarge by small amount. Overall, the risk of a congenitally affected offspring will be low.
  • Congenital myotonic dystrophy is associated with polyhydramnios, reduced fetal movements, talipes, neonatal hypotonia, facial diplegia, thin ribs, and poor respiratory efforts.
  • Cataracts are a feature in later life but not at birth.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2969)

choices.text: If both the parents are unaffected there is likely to be wrong paternity
There is increased risk of obstructive sleep apnea
Spinal cord compression is a recognized complication
There is likely to be heterozygous mutation in the FGFR3 gene

questions.text: Which of the following is false about achondroplasia?
questions.solution:
• Achondroplasia is autosomal dominant condition with high rates of new mutations (80%)
  • Almost all the patients have same mutation of FGFR3 gene.
  • The skull base and foramen magnum are small giving rise to increased risk of brainstem and cervical cord compression.
  • Sleep studies should be conducted where the child have noisy breathing or intermittent breathing, marked retraction, or snoring, particularly if their developmental milestones are lagging.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2146)

questions.text: In a child with bilateral lens dislocation, mild joint limitation and learning disability, the Most likely diagnosis is which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Closest differential is Marfan syndrome, but joints are lax and is not associated with learning disability.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2650)

questions.text: A Muslim couple are concerned about their offspring risks, given that they are first cousins, although they have no family history of any genetic disorder. Which of the following would be the MOST appropriate testing to offer them?
questions.solution:
• The autosomal recessive condition for which they are at greatest risk and for which carrier testing is available for β-thalassemia.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 595)

questions.text: A child has severe neonatal hypotonia. Which of the following is least likely to be the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• DMD does not present in neonates and infants.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2967)

questions.text: Most common cardiac complication with Myotonic dystrophy is?
questions.solution:
• Conduction defects are common in adults with myotonic dystrophy and can lead to arrythmias or sudden death.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2980)

choices.text: It is the commonest cause of microcytic anemia in infancy
Serum transferrin levels is the most reliable indicator, other than a bone marrow aspiration, of the total iron stores
The ratio of MCV to RBC count is useful differentiation from thalassemia
Decreased T cell function and cell mediated immunity is reported

questions.text: False statement about iron deficiency anemia in child is?
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of microcytic anemia in infancy is iron deficiency.
  • Serum ferritin is a reliable indicator of total iron stores, rather than serum transferrin. Bone marrow aspirate is the gold standard for documenting total iron stores.
  • The ratio of MCV to RBC count is useful in differentiating iron deficiency anemia from thalassemia. In iron deficiency anemia is less than 13 to 1 while in thalassemia it is greater than 13 to 1.
  • Deficiencies in immune system have been documented in iron deficiency, especially T cell function and cell mediated immunity.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2323)

choices.text: Congenital aplastic anemia is commoner than acquired
Fanconi's anemia is the commonest cause
Erythropoietin is an effective treatment in majority of the cases
Allogenic bone marrow transplantation is a recognized treatment option

questions.text: Which of the following statement about aplastic anemia is true?
questions.solution:
• Majority of aplastic anemias are acquired.
  • Despite the term aplastic anemia, all 3 cells lines are affected- resulting in anemia, leucopenia and thrombocytopenia. Erythropoietin is not effective treatment option in aplastic anemia.
  • Bone marrow transplantation is a well recognized treatment modality.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2370)

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is diagnosed having B cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following is associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
• Ataxia Telangiectasia is a chromosomal breakage disorder, characterized by ataxia, telangiectasia, and frequent sinopulmonary infections. Due to this condition being a chromosomal breakage syndrome, there is an association with malignancy, particularly leukemia and lymphoma.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 3128)

choices.text: It is commonest form of primary immunodeficiency
Has an association with Coeliac disease
Increases the risk of transfusion reactions

questions.text: False statement about IgA deficiency is
questions.solution:
• IgA deficiency is associated with autoimmune disorders like Coeliac disease, Crohn’s disease, Ulcerative colitis and malignancies.
  • Many patients will develop antibodies against immunoglobulin A and are at increased risk of anaphylaxis following transfusions as the donated blood will harbor IgA.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1015)

choices.text: To administer zoster immunoglobulin within 48 hours
To suspend the chemotherapy program and observe
To observe and administer zoster immunoglobulin if lesion develop

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy undergoes a course of intensive chemotherapy. He is known to be seronegative for herpes zoster. He is visited by his sister, who develops chickenpox the next day. What would be the most appropriate action be?
questions.solution:
• Chicken pox is infectious 24-48 hours before the rash appears, until the final lesion has crusted. In an immunodeficient person who is not immune to varicella zoster there is a clear indication for zoster immune globulin.
  • Acyclovir can be given for 7 days after exposure but it is of little benefit until the lesions develop.
  • It may be necessary to stop the chemotherapy but the most important step is to give ZIG within 48 hours.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1584)</

choices.text: Space occupying lesion in temporal lobe

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy complaint of headache in evening and sleeps earlier that night. The next morning, he is found to be drowsy and confused. He is admitted to the hospital and CT scan reveals swelling and enlargement of bilateral temporal lobe. The most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Temporal lobe involvement is characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection. CSF examination reveals raised cell counts with RBC present and raised protein but normal glucose levels.
  • SOL will be unilateral and it has gradually developing symptoms.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1576

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is investigated for weight loss, abdominal pain and jaundice. A diagnosis of sclerosing cholangitis is made. He has history of recurrent chest infections and diarrheal illness. One of his brothers had died of pneumonia at the age of 18 months. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The scenario suggests X linked immunodeficiency and history of sclerosing cholangitis points towards hyper-IgM syndrome.
  • Affected boys are predisposed to infections from early infancy and are particularly susceptible to Cryptosporidium infections. This may lead to abdominal pain, diarrhea and may be associated with sclerosing cholangitis.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1016)

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is admitted to the hospital with history of fever and fatigue since 3-weeks. Your examination reveals pale mucous membranes and skin. You also find splenomegaly. You are concerned about a possible malignancy. What is the most common malignancy of childhood?
questions.solution:
• The most common malignancy in childhood is leukemia/lymphoma.
  • The most common solid tumor are CNS tumors followed by neuroblastoma and Wilms tumor.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2437)

questions.text: A 1-day old baby is observed in post-natal rounds to be having a loud harsh cardiac murmur at the left sternal edge. No features of cardiac failure, oxygen saturation is normal, and ECG is normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Those children with left to right shunt have no signs and symptoms on first day of life. However, those with outflow obstruction have a murmur from birth.
  • Pulmonary stenosis usually has no cyanosis, and all neonates have a dominant right ventricle, thus revealing no evidence of right ventricular hypertrophy.

(Ref. Park’s textbook of Paediatric Cardiology, 6th ed., pg. 184)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of long QT interval?
questions.solution:
Causes of long QT interval

  • Romano-Ward syndrome
  • Jervell-Lange-Nielsen syndrome
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Head injury
  • Hypothermia
  • Drugs like Cisapride, erythromycin

(Ref. Park’s textbook of Paediatric Cardiology, 6th ed., pg. 428)

questions.text: Symptomatic CNS involvement is most commonly seen in which congenital infection?
questions.solution:
• Most of the congenital infection are asymptomatic at birth and develops symptoms later in infancy.
  • Most common organisms showing CNS manifestations are Rubella and Herpes virus.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1549)

questions.text: Zebra stripped hair is a characteristic of which micronutrient deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Zinc deficiency shows Zebra stripped hair. It might develop into alopecia if left untreated.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 344)

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presents with diarrhea since last 1 week. The examination reveals skin lesions as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• These are crusting dermatitis in perioral region. Child also has prolonged diarrhea which had led to zinc deficiency.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 344)

choices.text: Vitamin K is only required if the baby is going to be breast fed
Vitamin K is easily absorbed from the gut so there is no advantage to intramuscular injection
Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin
Too much Vitamin K can lead to bleeding disorders

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Vitamin K in newborn?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin K is fat soluble and so is less well absorbed in mothers and babies with liver disease, when repeat parenteral doses may be required.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 799)

choices.text: Cleft lip is always associated with cleft palate
Cleft palate is always associated with cleft lip
Cleft lip and palate are repaired together at 6-9 months
Cleft palate is repaired at 9 months to help develop speech

questions.text: True statement about cleft lip is?
questions.solution:
• The lip is repaired first at 3 months and later palate at 9 months.
  • Presence of one defect is not necessarily associated with presence of other. They might be present singly.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1771)

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to you with complaints of bloody diarrhea since last 2 days. Child is admitted and investigations are sent, that reveals altered renal function tests and peripheral smear as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The peripheral smear shows schistocytes with lysed RBC. Also, platelet counts are reduced (thrombocytopenia).
  • Onset of HUS occurs a few days after onset of gastroenteritis with fever, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. The prodromal intestinal symptoms may be severe and require hospitalization, but they can also be relatively mild and considered trivial. The diarrhea is often bloody but not necessarily so. Following the prodromal illness, the sudden onset of pallor, irritability, weakness, and lethargy heralds the onset of HUS. Oliguria can be present in early stages but may be masked by ongoing diarrhea, because the prodromal enteritis often overlaps the onset of HUS, particularly with ingestion of large doses of toxin.
  • The diagnosis is made by the combination of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with schistocytes, thrombocytopenia, and some degree of renal involvement.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2508)

questions.text: 5-year-old girl presents with complaints of bleeding PV since last 2 years. On examination there is a hyperpigmented patch and shown. The X ray femur shows advanced bone age to chronological age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This syndrome is characterized by precocious puberty, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia and Café au lait spots.
  • The average age of onset in affected girls is 3 years, but vaginal bleeding has occurred as early as 4 months and secondary sex characters have occurred as early as 6 months age.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2660)

questions.text: A peripheral smear in one of the admitted child is shown as follows. Such RBC are seen in all the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
• The peripheral smear finding is suggestive of Acanthocytosis.
  • This morphologic finding is seen with alterations in the cholesterol: phospholipid ratio in some patients with liver disease or vitamin E deficiency, and in congenital abetalipoproteinemia or hypoprebetalipoproteinemia, associated with fat malabsorption, neuromuscular abnormalities, and retinitis pigmentosa

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2335)

choices.text: It can entirely be prevented by using breast milk instead of formula milk
It is twice more likely to occur in formula fed babies then breast feds
It is diagnosed by observing abdominal distention

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)?
questions.solution:
• Babies given breast milk have half the incidence of formula fed babies but it still cannot be entirely prevented. There is evidence that probiotics such as bifidobacter and lactobacillus can further reduce the risk, even in breast-milk fed babies.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 838)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a reason to discontinue breast feeding at birth?
questions.solution:
• There are very few reasons when breastfeeding should be avoided. One is when the mother is taking medications which are excreted in the milk, such as warfarin. HIV in Western countries is another, but as the risk of infection in developing countries is high, breastfeeding is still recommended in HIV infected mothers. Breast engorgement and sore nipples are not a reason to stop breastfeeding.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 801)

questions.text: The ABC approach is one of the effective management techniques for temper tantrums. What does that stand for?
questions.solution:
• ABC is a useful approach when exploring and managing behavioral concerns. It reminds one to ask about precipitating events, a description of the behavior and the consequences (how the event is handled). Guidance can then be tailored.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 175)

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents with swollen cervical glands. Which of the following should not be included in the diagnostic profile?
questions.solution:
• T4 and TSH may be abnormal in thyroiditis, but the thyroid is a midline swelling, whereas cervical glands lie laterally in the anterior or posterior cervical angles delineated by the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The other tests can be considered if the child is very sick or the glands persist.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2414)

choices.text: Blood culture to be taken when fever breaks
Is usually due to atypical presentation of common illness
Absence of fever and sweating is sign of occult disease

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO)?
questions.solution:
• PUO is usually due to an atypical presentation of a common illness such as urine infection or pneumonia.
  • In adolescents PUO is defined as a fever for more than 2-3 weeks, but in young children the definition is fever for more than one week.
  • The absence of fever and sweating suggests factitious fever rather than organic disease.
  • Blood cultures should be obtained at the peak of fever as the yield is then higher. During the investigation phase of PUO antipyretics should be avoided as they will obscure the pattern of the fever.

    (Ref. Nelson’s Paediatric Symptom based diagnosis, pg. 701)
